debate.para: Mr. DEAKIN(Ballarat- AttorneyGeneral . - In view of the informationwhich has reached us, I take the first opportunity this morning to move, without notice-
That this House expresses its deep regret at the appalling disaster which has occurred in the Mount Kembla colliery, and its sympathy with the relatives of those who have been killed or injured.

The resolution is simplicity itself, as probably befits any reference to such a catastrophe. It appears that tragic incidents of this kind are inseparable from coal-mining, one of the greatest industries upon this or any other continent, and that the resources of science and the training of those engaged in the industry are alike unable to guard against awful sacrifices of human life, sudden and terrible. It is with the deepest regret that I submit this motion as some indication to those now suffering that their calamity has not passed unnoticed in this House, and that the representatives of Australia are all in sympathetic touch with them in their great affliction.

talk.start.para: - This motion must necessarily appeal to every honorable member of this House, and to every member of the community. It is one of the saddest features of our industrial life that men employed in mining and some other avocations carry their lives in their hands in their daily operations, and are occasionally stricken down, as these men have been, by an overwhelming disaster. We know that the men who work in mines are capable of performing deeds of quiet heroism. The facts are not always published, but if they were they would invariably justify our highest admiration. When we think of the domestic trouble caused by this lamentable disaster, our hearts must bleed for the unfortunate members of the families of those who have been stricken down. I second the motion.

- As the representative of the great mining community of Bendigo, I desire to express my fullest sympathy with the motion submitted by the Acting Prime Minister. In times past we have had very many mining accidents of a tragic and fearful character in Bendigo and other parts of Victoria, but never such an appalling disaster as this.' Perhaps never in the history of Australia has there been such a dreadful wreck of human life, with all the consequent prospective human misery. I desire to express my own sympathy and that of the minors of Bendigo, and of Australia generally, and I trust that when the proper time arrives everything possible will be done to lessen the misery resulting from this dreadful catastrophe, and that those who have been involved in suffering will have the hearty assistance and substantial support of the people of the Commonwealth.

speech.para: Mr.FULLER (Illawarra).- As the representative of 'the district in which this unfortunate accident has occurred, I desire to join with the Acting Prime Minister and those who have spoken to the motion, in expressing my sympathy with those who have been afflicted. In my position as representative of the district, I knew many of the men who have been stricken down. Unfortunately some of the heroic men who attempted to save the doomed miners have sacrificed their lives, among them being Major McCabe, one of the leading men in the district. Thisadds to the very serious consequences of the disaster, and, I join with other members in expressing my sincere sympathy with those who have been overwhelmed with sorrow.

talk.start.para: - As one largely interested in an adjoining property, I feel that it would not be out of place on my part to express my deepest sympathy with those who are suffering in consequence of the disaster. The sad loss of life and- disiocating of trade will be attended with disastrous consequences to the district, and,' so far as I am concerned, and the company with which I am connected,everything possible will be done to help those who are suffering.

- I think the Acting Prime Minister is to be complimented upon having given the House an opportunity to express its feelings in regard to this disaster. I do not. suppose there are any of us who do not feel the deepest sympathy with all the relatives of the men who have been killed or injured. The disaster is, unfortunately, one of several that have occurred in New South Wales, and the only relief we can feel in the midst of the present trouble is afforded by the knowledge that some steps have been taken in the past to provide for such emergencies as that which has now arisen, and that relief will be afforded to those who are left behind. There is no necessity to say more than that we are all in sincere accord with the motion.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: - May I suggest, Mr. Speaker, that you will be good enough, on behalf of the House, to forward this resolution, by telegraph, to the Mayor of Wollongong.
- I shall be happy to do so.

- I desire to ask the Acting Prime Minister whether the Government will grant £10,000 or £15,000 towards assisting the families of the unfortunate victims. In the case of the disaster at Mount Pelee the American Government voted £100,000 for the assistance of the sufferers.
- The considerations involved in the honorable member's question will require serious deliberation.

- I desire to know whether the Secretary for Home Affairs will lay upon the table the correspondence which has passed between the Superintendent of Public Works in South Australia and his department, with reference to the charge of 10 per cent.for supervision in connexion with the carrying out of works for the Commonwealth?

- I have no objection to lay the correspondence before the House. I regret that I was not present last night when certain references were made to this matter by one honorable member from South Australia.
- I desire to know when the report of Judge Dashwood on the pearl-shelling industry at Thursday Island will be available ?
- As soon as the Government Printer can publish it. The report is accompanied by maps and tables of figures, and the printing will therefore occupy a little longer time than usual.

subdebateinfo.title: APPROPRIATION OF REVENUE FOR PUBLIC WORKS

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: COOK, Joseph
Mr JOSEPH COOK

talk.start.para: - I desire to ask the Treasurer whether, in view of the recent debates on the subject of loans, and the necessity of carrying out certain public works without delay, he intends to continue to hand over to the States month by month all the surplus revenue, instead of appropriating some part of it for the construction of public works.

- I have no power to retain any portion of the money. The Constitution compels me to return month by month the amount collected in each particular State, after deducting the amount expended upon transferred services in that State and the State's share of the new expenditure. Thequestion whether we should affirm the principle of appropriating revenue for the construction of these works, to which loan funds have hitherto been applied, is one that honorable members will have to carefully consider, because it will probably involve taking revenue from the poorer States of Tasmania and Queensland for the purpose of carrying out works in New South Wales andVictoria.
- Queensland is not a poor State.

- I am speaking from the revenue stand-point. The matter is one which we shall have to very carefully discuss, and I propose to give honorable members an opportunity to consider it when I bring forward the Estimates - during the current month, I hope.

speech.para: An Honorable Member. - Why not bring them forward at once ?

talk.start.para: - The trouble is that we cannot obtain the necessary information.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: COOK, Joseph
Mr JOSEPH COOK

talk.start.para: - Could not the Treasurer almost at once consult the House, and thus settle the policy of the Commonwealth with regard to minor public works, so that he may make the necessary appropriations, and forthwith proceed with the works, which are now practically suspended for want of funds ?

- We cannot decide what we shall do with the surplus revenue until we know what the financial position of each individual State will be, and how the expenditure of acertain amount of money would affect it. I proposed to pay for these works out of loan funds, but honorable members were pretty evenly divided upon the question whether they should be constructed out of loans or out of revenue. If honorable members are prepared to affirm the principle that these works should be constructed out of loan funds, well and good, but I cannot ask them to consent to the works being paid for out of revenue until we ascertain the financial position of the States: It is difficult at present to obtain the necessary information to enable us to frame the Estimates, and the Defence Estimates have to be practically redrafted owing to the heavy reductions made. I hope to be able to deliver my financial statement by the middle of this month, and the House can then discuss the question whether these works should be constructed out of surplus revenue.
- Why are we not discussing the Estimates now, instead of wasting time in the consideration of measures which there is no prospect of passing?
-The Estimates are not yet prepared.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: COOK, Joseph
Mr JOSEPH COOK

talk.start.para: - In the meantime, will the right honorable gentleman- make a substantial advance to allow of some of thesE works being proceeded with 1

- The House was good enough to provide me with an advance of £50,000. A large proportion of that sum had to be appropriated to paydebts which had been incurred in Queensland, and which could not otherwise be discharged. The advance, therefore, has been practically exhausted, and I have to carry on other works with the money that is in hand. I cannot provide the funds necessary for large undertakings, but all minor works which are absolutely necessary are, I believe, being carried out.

debate.para: In Committee(Consideration resumed from 31st Jul}', vide page 14S05) :

quote.para: The Governor-General may authorize the payment out of the Consolidated Revenue Fund, which is hereby appropriated for the purpose, of bonuses on the manufacture in Australia after the commencement of this Act of the goods specified in the schedule to this Act according to the rates set out in the said schedule. Provided that no bonus shall be paid in respect of pig-iron, puddled bar iron, iron or steel pipes or tubes, or steel, unless the same is manufactured in works operated by a State Government.

debate.para: Upon which Mr. Kingston had moved, by way of amendment -

quote.para: That all the words after the word "schedule," line 7, be omitted,

talk.start.para: - When this matter was previously before the committee I spoke at some length, and I have no desire to traverse the ground which I then covered. Considering the inordinate length of the session and the urgency which exists for bringing it to a close, I regret that the Government should have revived this Bill, especially when there are important measures awaiting consideration. To my mind legislative action in connexion with this matter might very well have been deferred for the present, and a fair opportunity given to the States to decide whether or not they are prepared to embark upon the iron industry. Last night the Minister for Trade and Customs made a very impassioned address, from which I gathered that he is strongly in sympathy with the view entertained by a number of honorable members that this industry ought to receive special attention at the hands of the States Governments. Yet, because he has received a message from the States Premiers indicating that they are not prepared to immediately nationalize the work of iron production, he abandons his convictions and invites the committee to adopt the original proposition of the Government. Surely the Minister realizes that lightning changes occur in politics, and that very frequently a Government hostile to a measure to-day are its strong advocates to-morrow. The honorable member for Bland instanced a number of such changes in the New South Wales Legislature, pointing out that. important measures like the Old-Age Pensions Bill, and the Arbitration Bill, had been placed upon the statute-book through the instrumentality of men who had previously opposed them. I have in my mind a further instance. Just about twelve months ago I introduced to the present Premier of that State a representative deputation of farmers and settlers, who requested that legislation should be enacted to assist land-holders by making monetary advances. The Premier strongly opposed such a step, as an unnecessary and unwise interference in the domain of private enterprise. Before the session closed, however, he had evidently realized the error of his ways, seeing that he had introduced and passed through the Parliament a measure which practically gave effect to the views of the deputation. If the Bill under consideration be passed, and the same amount of pressure is brought to bear upon the New South Wales Government, I am convinced that history will repeat itself.
- The honorable member is referring to the Advances to Settlers' Bill 1

- I am referring to tm> Advances to. Settlers' Amendment Bill. The original Act provided for advances to settlers in the drought-stricken areas only. But what I desire to emphasize is that, despite the unfavorable reply which the deputation received, the period for repaying loans has been extended from ten to 30 years, the maximum advance has been increased from £200 to £500, and the Bill has been made applicable to land-holders general]}'-. I claim that if any industry ought to be under the direct control of the State, it is the iron industry. I know that some gentlemen view such a doctrine with suspicion, because they regard it as an incursion into the domain of practical socialism. Their inconsistency, however, is evidenced by their admission that the' State ownership of the railways, telephone and telegraph systems, has been amply justified. This is an experiment upon similar lines, and I hold that the nationalization of the iron industry will be abundantly warranted by results. In support of that contention, I would point out that there is a great dissimilarity between the Australian States and other .communities, such as Canada and America. In those countries the railways, which are the largest consumers of iron, are in the hands of private enterprise. In launching upon the work of iron production, a State would be assisting its railways, which consideration furnishes an additional reason why the industry should be nationalized. Further, the iron industry is the mother of all others.
- It is the backbone of most industries.

- Exactly. It is an industry which, if handed over to a private company, will place that company in a position to dictate terms to every other industry. From the very outset, therefore, it should be placed upon the same footing as our railways, telegraphs, and telephones, I am surprised that, because of a little opposition from various States, the Minister for Trade and Customs should feel called upon to take his hand from the plough and to look back. If he wishes to plough a straight furrow in connexion with this matter, he must look forward. In my previous remarks upon this question I stated that if I had to choose between granting this industry indirect assistance by means of the Tariff, and direct encouragement by the payment of a bonus, I should prefer the latter course. At the same time I added that I would rather grant a bonus to the States' Governments than to private enterprise. That is the attitude which I assumed, and I am prepared to abide by it. But if the proposal to nationalize the iron industry is defeated, I ' shall not fight against assisting private enterprise in this particular direction,

speech.para: Although I shall endeavour to see that the interests of the taxpayer are properly safeguarded. In submitting this proposal to the committee I claim that the Minister for

Trade and Customs has not supplied honorable members with sufficient information to warrant them in taking the step which he asks If this were merely a question of voting £250,000 for the assistance of some private company, it would lose some of its importance. We have to remember, however, that in order to raise .the amount we shall have to impose additional taxation to the extent of £1,000,000 ; and, under the circumstances, the necessity for information and for thoroughly safeguarding the interests of the taxpayer is accentuated. Canada has, I suppose, experimented more extensively with the bonus system than has any other British community. The Dominion Government have followed different lines from those which have hitherto been adopted in Australia. The States here have directly undertaken the work of developing our natural resources by means of railway extension, harbor accommodation, and postal and telegraph conveniences, whereas the Canadian policy has been, to assist private enterprise by the granting of bonuses. We are invited by the Minister to take Canada as our example in dealing with the establishment of the iron industry, and he has quoted figures showing the great development which has followed the application of the bonus system in that country. The Blyth River Iron Mining Company, who strongly urge the adoption of the bonus system, have circulated a reprint of an article from the Canadian Iron and Steel Industry Magazine of May, 1902, and I presume we may regard the statements therein as reliable. In that article it is stated that the number of blast-furnaces in Canada is about fourteen, and that there are four in course of construction, and four more projected. It is estimated that the total capacity of the furnaces in existence and in course of construction in Canada represents 1,090,300 tons.

talker.party: FT; ANTI-SOC from 1906; LP from 1910; NAT from 1917
talker.name: COOK, Joseph
Mr JOSEPH COOK

talk.start.para: - The total consumption in Canada last year was only 190,000 tons.
- No ; that was the consumption of pig iron only.

-The production rose from 44,791 tons, in 1894, to 244,976 tons, in 1901, and, according to the article, the output of the Canadian furnaces is 22 per cent, of the capacity, as against 60 per cent, in the case of the furnaces in the United States. On a per capita basis the production in the United States is four times that in Canada, the former being 475 lbs., and the latter 110 lbs. The writer of the articlestrongly favours the bonus system, but he urges the very significant contention that a duty or bonus should be so framed as to be efficient in hard times as well as in good times. The true import of that statement is found in a table which shows theamounts which have been expended in bonuses in Canada. In 1884 the amount paid was 44,090 dollars, and every year shows a variation, until in 1891 the figure is 20,153 dollars. In 1901 the expenditure had increased to 351,259 dollars, showing that there have been periods of prosperity and periods of depression. Much is said about great benefits which result to wage-earners from the introduction of capital by means of the bonus system, and to hear the arguments usually advanced one would suppose that the wages fund was wholly drawn from capital. But the common experience of hard-headed, practical commercial men is that capital does not pay wages for any very lengthened period - that if wage-earners are not able to produce their own wage fund and a little over, an industry very quickly comes to a standstill, and the wage-earners have to seek elsewhere for employment which will enable them to provide the fund. (Committee counted.)
- When that happens capital, as a rule, has gone also.

- Capital will not stay long where any very great demands are made on it, no matter what the industry or the assistance granted may be. There is a further paragraph in the article, which I commend to the honorable member for Melbourne Ports, who is the high -priest of protection in Victoria. Thecontention of that honorable member when the Tariff was under review was that protective duties, whilst blocking importation, result in the decreasing the prices of commodities within the charmed circle on which its benefits are conferred. The article states that the Canadian mineowners have to face unfair competition at the hands of the American mine-owners, who are selling iron in Canada at 3 dollars per ton less than American consumers have to pay for the same article. Under the circumstances, it is contended that further assistance should be given, and in the Argus or Age of yesterday may be found a cable message stating that a new steel corporation has been founded in Canada for the purpose of meeting and resisting the competition. This corporation has a capital of £3,600,000, and it is to receive assistance from the Canadian Government by way of bonus to the extent of £1,000,000, with the further extraordinary concession of exemption from the federal taxation for twenty years. It is anticipated that by these means the mine-owners of Canada will be able not only to meet the competition of the American mine-owners, but also to produce iron 30 per cent. cheaper than is possible in America. The bonus system in Canada has been in vogue for a number of years, and, as there has been fair opportunity to demonstrate its good as well as its bad qualities, the results should prove instructive when it is proposed that we should embark on a similar policy. It will be readily admitted, I think, that the Economist is a reliable and competent authority on politicofinancial questions. In that publication of 3rd May this year there is an article from a Canadian correspondent on the subject of Canadian finances, and it appears that the Dominion Government, by way of loans which have been converted into subsidies, and by subscriptions for shares and subsidies direct, have expended 200,000,000 dollars, or about £40,000,000.

speech.para: An Honorable Member. - On the iron industry ?

talk.start.para: - No; on general subsidies, mainly on railway construction, waterways, and so forth. The provincial Governments of Canada have expended £6,600,000 in this direction, and the municipalities £3,600,000, or a total of £50,000,000, and this is in addition to other concessions. In connexion with railway construction the Canadian Government, besides giving monetary assistance in the way of enormous subsidies, has given something like 50,000,000 acres of land to private companies in order to encourage and promote the construction of railways. The article says -

quote.para: The St. Lawrence water route,from the Great Lakes to Montreal and Quebec, has cost the Canadian taxpayer 100,000,000 dollars; and there are several other works in projection which will cost enormous sums of money. The article mentions these facts as showing the abuses that may arise under the bonus-giving system. It points out that subsidies have been given for the extension of these facilities on the ground of public services and advantages, and that the private companies have controlled the works in their own special interest, so that the communities affected have asked for the construction of opposition lines for the purpose of getting a "fair deal " by the roundabout method of competition. The Dominion Government are asked to subsidize the construction of those opposition lines, or to spend money in their construction. This must be admitted to be a wasteful expenditure, which would have been avoided if the Canadian Government had followed the wiser and more enlightened System adopted in Australia of constructing lines of railway by the State and running them in the public interest. The article in the Economist goes on to say that-

The other day the New Brunswick Legislature was only just prevented from guaranteeing the bonds of a railway several years old, which had been hawked about for sale since 1897, the object being to benefit certain speculators.

speech.para: Then it goes on to refer to a matter which should receive the serious attention of this committee and of the Government, and points out that the system of granting bonuses has had a demoralizing influence upon the political life of Canada. It has introduced a system of log-rolling, of watering stocks, and so forth. Perhaps I cannot do better than quote a short paragraph dealing with this particular phase in the words of the writer : -

quote.para: It is scarcely necessary to say that a good deal of corruption in Dominion, provincial, and municipal affairs is engendered by thissystem. Thesubsidy is almost always ' ' milked " by the politicians who grant it, while the contractor, whose profit comes from construction, and sometimes, too, by handling the bonds, takes care of those, in or out of Parliament, who may be disposed to question the wisdom of developing the country in this fashion. It is only right to add, however, that the best men on both sides of politics would like to see the whole business abandoned. Unfortunately, the promoters and contractors have madea great many people believe that subsidies are necessary to enable us to keep step in material advancement with the United States, an argument which every census shows to be fallacious, and which at best is merely saying that it is right to do evil that good may come.

speech.para: Unfortunately our information on Canadian matters has hitherto been very limited, even though the Dominion is part of the great British Empire to which we belong. I trust that the tendency of drawing all parts of the Empire together will have such an influence that in the near future we shall know very much more of Canada than has been the case in the past, and that Canada will know more of us. The article I have quoted seems to me to indicate grave reasons why we should enter upon this system of granting bonuses to private companies only with a great deal of care, and that we should at least have sufficient information to indicate what are the dangers to be avoided, and how best to safeguard the public expenditure under the policy to which we are asked to commit the Commonwealth. I intend strongly to oppose the Government in the proposal now submitted, and to en- deavour to have the Bill passed in the form in which it was amended at the instance of the honorable member for Bland. That is not unreasonable. If the Bill be so passed it will give an incentive to those States that like the idea of working their iron deposits to set to work in that direction, and if they are unsuccessful no great harm will have been done. I know that on the Opposition side of the Chamber there are some honorable members who. are altogether opposed to the granting of bonuses, and who believe that if an industry is to be left to private enterprise at all, it should be left to it entirely. Some of those who voted for the proposal of the honorable member for Bland felt that if it comes to be a question of choosing between bonuses to private enterprise, or to the States Governments, theywould prefer to leave the matter under the control of the Governments. But I understand that some of those honorable members are now inclined to question the wisdom of that course. I want them fairly to face this phase of the matter - which do they prefer, bonuses to private individuals without restriction as set out in this Bill, or bonuses to the States Governments? If they prefer the method of granting bonuses to the States Governments they should, even though they would prefer to have no bonuses whatever, stand by the vote they previously gave. I venture to prophesy that if they go back upon their former vote, the alternative course will be carried whether they like it or not.

Mr. HIGGINS(Northern Melbourne).It is lamentable that we should be coming to a dead-lock with regard to this measure, considering the very small line of demarcation between the views of honorable members, and the fact that the vast importance of the iron industry is generally recognised. It is evident from the remarks of the last speaker that he recognises the iron industry to be a parent industry, one from which other industries branch, on which other industries lean, and which will give work and new resources to the people of Australia for a long time to come. Upon that point there is a general agreement; and I think also that there is a large majority in the House who would like to see so valuable and so cardinal an industry in the hands of the State. They recognise that it is not safe, in the interests of the people, to leave such an industry in the hands of private enterprise. I, at all events, am one of those who, rightly or wrongly, believe that. But although I may not see my way to the State taking up the matter at the present time, I think it would be lamentable if the iron industry were not started. I do not think it will be started by a State Government. I should like, therefore, to make a suggestion- that we should insert a clause in the Bill to the effect that, if bonuses be granted to any private company or firm, there shall be an option for the State to take over the industry at a valuation to be fixed, upon giving a certain notice.

talk.start.para: - A good method of putting difficulties in the way of the State ever doing the work !
- Nothing of the sort. It would stillbe open to a State to start the industry.
- An honorable member who believes in the State engaging in the industry should vote straight in that direction.

- Each one is entitled to his own view. But there is this point to be considered - that the State is not a good pioneer of industry. Nearly all industries are pioneered by private enterprise. The selectors in the back-blocks made rough roads for their own purposes in the first instance. You also find the selectors establishing their own temporary postoffices. It is private enterprise that often erects the first schools, and so with nearly all the other requisites of civilized life. After private enterprise has established these things, the State comes along and puts them in order.
- The State pioneered the railways in Australia.
- I am not arguing against the honorable member's principle.
- Is the honorable and learned member speaking on behalf of the Government ?

- The honorable member for Macquarie, from his official position upon the opposition side of the Chamber, no doubt knows whether the Government is in favour of this proposal or not. But it does not concern me whether or not the Government is. I am.
- The honorable and learned member took up a similar position for the Government in regard to the GovernorGeneral's allowances.

- I do not know what the Governor-General has to do with iron ore. I think it would be an advantage to the particular State of the Commonwealth which took up this industry if the pioneering work were done by private enterprise. It is like the case of the shark and the pilot fish. The pilot fish comes along and nibbles at a piece of meat, and then the shark - if I may compare the State to the shark - puts in an appearance, drives the pilot fish away, and takes the food.
- Does the honorable and learned member think that the iron industry would be run by business men or philanthropists ?

- By business men. I recognise that men would not take up an industry unless they hoped to make money out of it. Honorable members will perhaps recollect that I suggested an alteration in one of the clauses, tothe effect that any company or body of persons who obtained the bonus should do so subject to certain terms with regard to the wages and hours and conditions of labour of its employés. I think that there might also be a Specific provision in the Bill to the effect that no bonus shall be paid to any company or persons except upon the condition that a State may buy them out at a valuation to be settled by arbitration, and upon a basis which has yet to be thought out. The pioneering work would then be done by private profit-seekers, and in the course of a few years, when the States Governments had become more amenable to reason, as I hope they will be, we should be able to compel them to take over the industry and to work it upon lines which experience might dictate. In our present financial system it would not be advisable for a State to enter into a huge enterprise of this kind. It would be like entering into an unknown country. Let the country first be explored and tested. There is a great advantage in giving a bonus. If we give a bonus we know exactly how much we are spending ; we know what we can afford to lose, and we have no care, no worry, and no responsibility. But if a State should be the first to enter upon the establishment of the iron industry, it would have to work a most difficult undertaking under unknown conditions. I would not presume to say how far the industry would succeed in Australia for some years ; having regard to the conditions operating in America, and in Canada, particularly, I would not say how far it might not be undercut from outside. Until private enterprise has clone the exploration work, I should not like to see any State enter into a business which might involve a great many incidental calls upon the public purse. I think it is a dangerous thing. I .say this hoping, at the same time, that in the course of a few years the business will be carried on by one of the States. I should much prefer it to be conducted by the Commonwealth than by any of the individual States, but that cannot be done.
- Why not ?
- Because the Constitution will not allow it.
- We were told in New South Wales that the Constitution could be amended in the easiest possible manner. I admit that the honorable and learned member did not say so. ,

- That is the old story. We have to deal with existing facts and make the best of what I might call a bad job. The next best thing to the establishment of the industry by the Commonwealth is that it should be taken up by one of the States, and a State would enter upon it to the greatest advantage at a time when it could profit by the experience of the private profit-seeker. I have never known an industry to be taken up by the State which had not previously been tested by private profit-seekers. The State often fails, but when it does succeed, it succeeds always in cases in which it has followed the experience of the private profit-seeker. With all respect to the honorable member for Bland, I think that those who are advocating the immediate thrusting of the iron industry into the control of the State are the enemies of the State working of monopolies. This is a monopolistic industry, but it is a mistake to desire the States to set the ball rolling. We cannot get the State to work with its cumbrous machinery until we have had the experience of men who commence operations for the mere purpose of profit.
- The railways were new when the State took them up here.
- That is a very different thing, but we had private railways in Victoria. The first railway in Victoria was constructed by private enterprise.
- I am informed that the first line constructed in Victoria was that running from Melbourne to Williamstown, and that it was built bv the State.

- We had the Hobson's Bay line, and also the Geelong to Melbourne railway was built by a private company. All that I am putting is that in view of the tremendous movements to control the output of iron and rails in America and elsewhere, it is impossible. for us to foresee how the iron industry will succeed here. There are men who are willing to risk their capital in it, provided that they have a chance of making reasonable profits.
- Would they enter upon it with the certainty that their works would be taken from them if they established them successfully ?

- That is a mere question affecting the conditions to be imposed. I think the honorable member is quite right in saying that a man who believed it possible that if he successful^ established an industry it would be taken from him, would be chary in entering upon it. But if we provide conditions which will show those who may think of entering upon the industry that they will not. be robbed of the fruits of their labours, they will be far more likely to take it up. It is foi- this reason that I still adhere to the view which I took when the committee last divided upon this question, and I shall certainly vote for the excision of the proviso. I voted on a former occasion for a modified excision of the words, but that proposal was not accepted. I should still vote for it if it were proposed, but it is not. A compromise has been suggested by the honorable member for Melbourne Ports that no bonus should be paid to any private company or individual for a period of two years, in order that the States might have time to take up the industry. That proposition was not accepted. I should be willing, although with regret, to adopt it. I prefer to see the proviso omitted, so as to leave the industry to private enterprise in the first instance, and when that had done the pioneer work, to enable a State to take it up.

- I have listened with some surprise to the peculiar proposition for encouraging the iron industry, which has been made by the honorable and learned member for Northern Melbourne. His proposal is that a bonus of £250,000 shall be given to private individuals.
- That is not so.

-j-The proposal is, I suppose, that the Bill should be passed, as the Minister desires, in a shape providing for a bonus of £250,000 to be paid' to private individuals who enter upon the iron industry, and that at some period subsequent 'to the payment of that bonus a State should take up the industry. Presumably the honorable and learned member proposes that the State shall take it up only if it is a success. If it is a failure, the State is carefully to-let it alone. If the honorable and learned member's proposal were carried out it would mean that private individuals would be induced to establish the industry by their own enterprise and perhaps at considerable loss, the State contributing £250,000 to make good that loss. But as soon as they had proved that the industry could be successfully carried on the State would say to them - "We will take your property, work it ourselves, and annex the profits."
- At a fair valuation.

- Take it, I presume, on payment for the works and land. Any one who enters upon such an industry does not look to the profits of the first few years to recoup him. He looks to their continuance for an indefinite period - to the accumulated profits for his return.
- We should have to recompense them accordingly.

- Of course. If the honorable and learned member means that on taking over the works the State should pay the owners a sum representing not merely the money expended upon them and 10 pei' cent, as compensation for resumption, but an amount based upon the anticipated profits for a considerable number of years, I do not think it would be a good thing for the State to entertain. On the other hand, if a State could take over the property on paying merely an additional 10 per cent, for resumption, surely it would be impossible to find any individual so simple as to enter into the industry.
- The honorable member's argument is against all option to purchase.
- If it is desired to establish the iron industry it cannot be well done with an option to purchase.
- Indeed it can. Nearly every Act authorizing the construction of a private railway Or tramway gives to the Government or local authority the right to purchase it after a certain time.
- After a considerable number of years.
- That is so ; but I do not understand that the suggestion here is that it should be done at once.
- There is far more trouble in establishing an iron industry than in constructing a railway or a tramway.
- Regulations could deal with question of terms.
- I suppose the Minister is favorable to this proposal, as he is defending it 1
- r favour anything which asks fora fair protection of the State.

- We are beginning to see that this proposal is made under the wing of the Government. If the Minister anticipates starting an iron industry under these conditions, I am very much afraid that he will be disappointed. I was rather amused at his touching references to his belief in a State iron industry, and his regret that no State had seen fit to undertake its establishment. He says that a month ago that he hoped, and fervently believed, that some State might embark in this enterprise, and for that reason he accepted with delight the amendment which he now resists.
- I did not say anything of the sort. Considering that I divided against the amendment, how could I have accepted it with delight?

- That is what the members of the committee understood. The Minister read the refusals of the States almost with tears in his eyes; and it is very astonishing that he resisted the proposal previously, and is resisting it to-day. He also spoke very touchingly, and no doubt truly, as to the great importance of the iron industry. But what does his proposal mean ? Does it recognise the importance of the iron

speech.para: I industry 1 It says that this large industry I can be established by giving a bonus of £250,000, and that it will not be created, whatever its prospects may be, without that gift. It is too big an industry to be affected by the offer of that bonus. If there is a profitable outlet for the enterprise, not for the first 'few years, but during the- course of many years - if investors can be convinced in that respect - they will not wait for a bonus of £250,000. If no profitable outlook is promised, no such sum will induce them legitimately to embark in the enterprise. If they do, it will be done simply in order to get hold of' that £250,000. They will float some concern on the markets of the world where the facts are not so well known as they may be to themselves, with the object of annexing the bonus, and the premium which will attach to flotation, owing to the gift of the bonus, and leave the company thus established to its fate. Either the bonus is not sufficient to induce the starting of the industry unless otherwise it can be a success, or the Minister means at a subsequent period to propose an additional bonus or duty if it is not successfully established. The Minister has .given a glowing picture of the growth of the iron industry in Canada, but what are the facts? Before the bonus was given Canada manufactured 36 per cent, of her own requirements in iron. What has been the result since the bonus was -given? Further bonuses have been asked for, higher duties have been requested, and to-day not a paltry £250,000, but millions are required to support this industry, which is said to have been so thoroughly established by the bonus system. Surely the Minister was unfortunate when he went to Canada for an example to us. Everything which is feared here has occurred there, and some of us feel that the course of embarking in this giving of bonuses in connexion with the iron industry will be attended with the same objectionable results as have occurred in Canada. In this case the Minister proposes to impose protective duties after the cessation of the bonus. It is not the bonus itself only that we have to deal with. Even under the Ministerial proposal there are to follow protective duties, which, we may feel certain, will not stand at the moderate level at which they are proposed, if the industry demands higher ones. Having brought into existence this bantling, it litis to be supported at all hazards. It must be brought to manhood if possible, and the State will be asked to do it.

talk.start.para: - The duties will be as high as necessity demands, and as low as circumstances permit.

- Here is a candid admission by the honorable member. We know what demands we had in other directions when we were framing the Tariff. But what are- the demands likely to be in connexion with the iron industry ? I am against the giving of any bonuses. I am asked to vote to give a bonus to a State. How can I legitimately and consistently give such a vote, especially as I am more opposed to a bonus being offered to fi State than to its being thrown open for the acceptance- of all 1 A strong objection to this assistance to industries is that it creates an opportunity to levy taxation from the people. Under a bonus, without coming duties, that cannot be done, I admit, to the same extent as can be done under .protective duties. In this case protective duties are to follow, whether a State or a private person takes up the industry and those duties rise with the necessity. My objection, and that of other free-traders who think with me, to that is that it creates an opportunity for taxation being drawn from the people of the State, or if that opportunity does not exist, because the duty is not sufficiently high to exclude competition by the outside world, then every industry, and every other consumer of its product is made to pay for the support of the producers. That is the position, and it is not relieved because the bonus is given to a State ; in fact, it is intensified. If a State establishes the industry, and it cannot compete easily with the outside world, it will get what it demands, to enable the continuance of the competition with the outside world. There will be a tax, levied on the consumers of the material.
- A State can pull less strings than a private syndicate in that connexion.
- I do not say that a. State would endeavour to get all the profits which a duty, if too high, would allow.
- As regards getting an increased bonus, or an increased duty, a private enterprise syndicate will pull more strings 'than a State can do.

- I believe that the honorable member is right in that respect, Only I think that the State would have more weight in the getting of the help. If the State is to do outside business, apart from meeting its own requirements, it will demand, and probably will get, this higher duty, which will handicap the other industries of the Commonwealth, because pf the prices which will have to be paid for the material it produces. As regards what it uses in its own departments - and that represents a very large proportion of the total consumption - even if . it costs 50 per cent, more than the article could be imported for, the State will use the product of its industry, and ' will make the people at large pay the extra prices, and thus support all those engaged in its production. That I consider is a national loss. Holding that opinion I cannot depart from my objection to vote for a bonus to a State. A.t the present stage there is really no question of a State industry versus a private industry. Any State, if it likes, can start an iron industry to-morrow.
- It could be done under private enterprise also.
- Under private enterprise also.
- How about the£250,000?

- Unless it is intended ss a means of getting something immediately by the flotation of a company which the company would have no light to get, scattered over an industry like the iron industry, which should run through the ages, £250,000 is a mere nothing. If the industry would not start without the bonus, it would not start with it. If the industry will start without the bonus, and it will if the opportunity is there, then it should not be given. Surely no State needs a bonus of £250,000 ? What « farce to offer that sum to the States ! Cannot the poorest and the weakest of the States find £250,000? Tasmania could raise that sum to-morrow if she wanted it, and so could any other State in the Commonwealth. From that aspect, the whole thing is ridiculous. There is nothing that may be put into this cr any Bill which will prevent any State, if it wishes, from embarking in the iron industry. For that reason also I do not see my way to support the giving of a bonus to the States. Then we . have this other question - although it is a most important one, the Minister has given us no information - how will it affect our financial position ? If we have to provide £100,000 a year for the payment of these bonuses, and if we are going, as the House has expressed its desire' that we should, to pay out of revenue much which hitherto has been paid out of loan account, where are we to get this sum of £100,000 a year from? Are we to raise £400,000 or £500,000 in order to provide for it ? If not, we should have some indication from Ministers regarding ways and means. The Loan Bill has not yet been passed, and may not be, and the Government should be able to tell us how they propose to find the money. In the interests of the industry itself, and of our own financial position, it would be infinitely better for the Ministry to allow this proposal to stand over for the present. The members of the labour party have expressed themselves against giving bonuses to private individuals.
- No, not all of us. We are all in favour of giving the preference to the States.
- - -Some of us, including myself, are against giving bonuses to private individuals.
- So am I, but others are not.

- The honorable member for Bland said yesterday that such a strong feeling existed in New South Wales in favour of the Government establishing the iron industry that, if some agitation were made, the Ministry would probably enter upon the industry before many months were over. If the view of the honorable member is correct, we had better, from his point of view, reject the Bill, and leave the States to take their own course.
- - Those who favour the establishment of State iron works in New South Wales say that we shall assist them if we pass this Bill.

- If this Bill were passed, the States Governments would probably not have the same opportunities of establishing the iron industry as would be afforded in the absence of federal legislation. The honorable member for Canobolas was wrong in stating that, if honorable members on this side of the Chamber supported the Government in excising the. provision for bonuses to the States, there was only one way to do it.

- If the Bill is passed in its present shape it will assist in the establishment of State iron works in New South Wales, because the Government of that State will then be able to obtain assistance from the other States.

- Does the honorable member suppose that a bonus of £250,000 is likely to influence the Government of New South Wales ? That State could raise ten times £250,000 if it desired to establish the iron industry. I intend to vote against bonuses in any form. I shall vote against this clause, and I trust that the Bill will be defeated. I am satisfied that by granting bonuses, either to the States Governments or to private individuals, we shall enter upon a policy the end of which we cannot see. The Commonwealth will be dragged into giving more and more support to any industry that may be created upon such a false basis. I look upon the proposal to grant £250,000 as worse than a scheme involving an outlay of £1,000,000.' If it were proposed to spend the larger sum we might look upon that as ending the matter, but a grant of £250,000 will simply introduce the thin end of the wedge. If the industry were started under that bonus we should have appeals for further assitance made to us within a very short time. We should be asked not to destroy that which we had created, for which the future held out great hopes of prosperity. A bonus of £250,000 would be a mere drop in the ocean. We must not look to the expenditure of a year or two in connexion with such an enterprise, but to an outlay extending over decades. If the opportunity presents itself the iron industry will be established upon : 1sound basis, and under such conditions that those engaged in other industries will not be required to contribute to its support, and consumers will not have to pay more for what they require. The industry will then grow with the progress of the Commonwealth, and may even, by means of an export trade, bring wealth to our shores from other parte of the world.

- I listened with great interest to the reason which the Minister gave for asking honorable members to reverse the decision previously arrived at. Although the right honorable gentleman spoke with great earnestness, and stated that he had the most convincing proof of the necessity for restoring the Bill to its original form, the facts adduced by him seemed to me to constitute the strongest arguments against his proposal. The information received from Canada proved that large sums of money had been spent by the Dominion Government, and that the ironworks had greatly increased their output, but, at the same time, we find that those engaged in the enterprise are still crying out for more assistance, and that there is no perceptible end to their demands. There are any number of men who will produce anything in the Commonwealth if the Government will, pay them to do so. The reports quoted by the Minister indicate that there are such dangers connected with the bonus system as should frighten every honorable member. I do not think that the reports from Canada had much to do with the desire of the Government to restore the Bill to its original form. I should be sorry to say that the lobbying which has been going on for some time past had anything to'do with their action ; but the fact that some honorable members have changed their opinion has, nodoubt, largely influenced them. They have been relying upon the count of noses rather than upon the figures from Canada. The honorable and learned member for Northern Melbourne made a most extraordinary proposal. He evidently thinks that a heavy loss will be incurred in connexion with the establishment of ironworks. He, therefore, suggests that a handsome- bonus should be granted to induce some one to undertake the experiment, his idea being that the State should, in the event of success, take over the works. Is it likely that the Government will be able to take over the industry unless they pay the firm for any loss which it lias incurred ? Would it not be a great deal safer for the State itself to find the money necessary to embark upon the undertaking ? The party with which I am associated are prepared to stir up public opinion upon this matter in New South Wales if the Bill in its present form becomes law. At the same time, we have just cause of complaint against the Minister' for Trade and Customs. When the amendment submitted by the honorable member for Bland was carried, we accepted his assurance that the Opposition had not succeeded in killing the 'Bill, and that the Government intended to proceed with it. It is a very big strain upon our faith, therefore, to find the Minister now attempting to reverse the decision arrived at by the committee, and it is misleading to the section with which we are associated. The replies received by the Minister from the States Governments are just what might have been expected. But despite the statement of the Premier of New South Wales, I hold that if the Bill passes in its present form he will be unable to resist the pressure of public opinion that will be brought to bear, and will be compelled to embark upon this industry. At the present time, however, he can excuse Government inaction by the plea that he has no assurance that the Bill will pass both Houses of this Parliament. As the honorable member for Bland has pointed out, past experience teaches that the States Governments will never enter upon any large undertaking until they are forced to do so by public opinion. In effect, the proposal of the Minister for Trade and Customs is to borrow money from one set of British capitalists for the purpose of advancing it to another. "We know that syndicates are always ready to secure privileges, which they dispose of to a large 'company, in which they receive a big share. In mining circles these individuals are known as "first robbers." If the industry does not pay they close down the works, and deputations wait upon -the Government pleading for further assistance, either by way of the payment of an increased bonus or the imposition of a higher duty, so that they may put money into their own pockets. Honorable members are practically asked to allow themselves to be used as mere tools for the benefit of a few capitalists in Great Britain. Even if the proposal of the Minister is assented to, we have not the slightest guarantee that the iron industry will be established by private enterprise. This is a question in which the labour party has taken a very keen interest for a considerable time, and I unhesitatingly say that the action of the Minister is calculated to defeat his own wishes. It i§ all very well to argue that none of the States Governments will embark upon this industry. But I would point out that New South Wales has a sufficient surplus income to engage in it even without any artificial aid. I venture to say that, if the Bill be carried in its present form, within a year or two one of the States will nationalize the industry.
- The Government offered to confine the Bill to the* States Govern^ ments for two years, but the party to which the honorable member belongs would not agree to the proposal.

speech.para: Mr. SPENCE.Syndicators do not care twopence whether or not the iron industry becomes established so long, as they can attack somebody's pockets ; There is always something rotten associated with appeals to the Government to aid private enterprise: The whole principle is a bad one. There is absolutely no justification for offering this- bonus at such an early stage in our federal history. At the present time we have not a penny to spare. We cannot get a telephone wire put across a street, at a coat of- 30s., 'because there is no money available, and yet it is proposed to offer private individuals £320,000 to engage in these industries. I do not like the look of this proposal, and I protest against the lobbying which has been going on within the precincts of this House.' We had. enough of that in connexion with the Tariff proposals. If only a man and a boy are engaged in an industry they can get almost anything for which they choose to ask from this Government. Of course lobbyists do not worry me, because my views upon this question are well known. Since I have occupied a seat in this Parliament I have been astonished to find prominent labour men interviewing honorable members on behalf of the British capitalist. To what is- the country coming when we witness that sort of thing? The time seems to be rapidly approaching, when we shall have to frame a standing order for the purpose of- preventing lobbying. When I see honorable members- professing certain principles- and deliberately placing, obstacles in the way of the realization of those principles, there is a big strain on my belief in their sincerity. The honorable member for North , Sydney, and others- who think with him, had better be careful or they will fail to accomplish the object they have in view. There are many who believe in the bonus system, and many who are opposed to it, and the voting will be somewhat mixed ; but I sincerely hope the committee will adhere to the previous decision. If the States fail to take the matter up" there will always be the opportunity for the Government to carry out their desire to encourage private enterprise. No doubt we have all received the circular to which reference, has already been made., and from the statements therein we can see that the drift in Canada is in the direction of monopoly. In Australia it is clear there would be a monopoly; practically, from the start ; and that means- that the Government would give away money which it had no right to give away, and the country would ultimately suffer. To resume the industry at some future time would prove a most costly and stupid method. It is idle to speak of experiment in connexion with one of the oldest industries in the world ; and the Government would be able to employ experts with as much or more ease than could any private company. We have theUnited States, England, and Canada, from which to select men of experience, and they would more readily work for a Government than for corporations who are not always the most satisfying of employers. Experiments in the iron industry have already been made elsewhere, and scientists could easily apply, at a comparatively trifling cost, any tests which might appear necessary.

talk.start.para: - The honorable member for Darling seems to have very great faith in State control, but he cannot have looked at the statistics which show the result ofthe management of Government railways and tramways. In Australia there are no Government tramways or railways which would not pay much better in the hands of private individuals.
- The Sydney tramways pay better than do the private tramways in Melbourne.

- The average return from the Australian railways is 3.21 per cent., but the dividends paid by the English companies and by companies in other parts of the world are much higher. The returns of the tramways in Sydney are 3.56 per cent., whereas in Brisbane, where there is a much smaller population of 120,000, private tramways return three or four times as much.
- I can give many instances in which tramways have been taken over by municipalities, and have paid much better than they did in private hands.

- The honorable member is dealing with tramways in the old country. In Australia there will be a sad state of affairs when we find State socialism creeping in and taking control of all enterprises, and especially an enterprise like the iron industry. The honorable member for North Sydney referred to iron manufacture in Canada prior to the granting of the bonuses, but he said nothing about the increase in the export of iron from that country. In 1892 the export of pig-iron from Canada was only 3 tons, whereas in 1901 it was 5,623 tons, and in the first eight months of the present financial year it reached the enormous figure of 68,669 tons, valued at 661,000 dollars. The increase of over 60,000 tons in eight months is, I contend, entirely due to the bonus.
- Does that not apply to the sugar industry on the continent ?
- I dare say it does.
- But all those in Australia who are interested in the sugar industry are. opposed to the continental bonuses.

- That is because those interested in the sugar industry desire to look after themselves. In Queensland we had a very good example of the effect of rejecting a proposal for granting what was equal to a bonus. In 1883 the Government of the State proposed to arrange for the construction of a transcontinental railway on the land-grant system ; but the idea was so strongly opposed by the combination of pastorolists and the labour party that the Government went out of office.
- The sum of £220,000 was ready to be paid in bribes directly the agreement was signed.

- If that railway had been, built in 1883, thousands of head of stock in Queensland would have been saved during the drought ; and the public of that State after twenty years have turned round and granted a concession to a Scotch syndicate to build a similar railway, feeling that in the present state of the finances, the Government are not able to undertake the enterprise. That is an instance which shouldbe seriously considered in connexion with the Bill before us. I do not.say that the State should not have the right to acquire any ironworks which maybe erected. In granting any concession, the State should reserve the right to come in at the expiration of some period and purchase-
- From that point of view, the honorable member ought to vote against the proposal of the Government.

- I shall not vote against the proposal of the Government, but I should not object to vote for such a period being allowed as to insure that those who start the works will be recouped for losses which will necessarily occur at the commencement of a venture of this nature. It would be ridiculous, however, to compel a company to sell to the Government at an advance of 10 per cent. at the end of, perhaps, four or five years, just when the works were beginning to pay, after losses had been incurred. Personally, I should rather see the Bill carried as now proposed, because its scope can be broadened at any time to enable the Government to step in and purchase. While I should not like to see the Bill lost because a provision of that kind was not inserted, still I prefer that it should not be inserted now. Frequent reference has been made by the honorable member for Darling to the necessity which has arisen for further assistance to the Canadian iron industry; but surely that honorable member has not looked carefully at the telegrams which have appeared in the press. The Government of Canada have seen that American combinations are likely to get control of the shipping between Canada and Great Britain, and, as would be done here in similar circumstances, it has been decided to contribute a bonus of £1,000,000, and give twenty years' exemption from wharfage and other charges in order to retain communication with the old country. The object is not to bolster up the iron industry, but to retain the present growing trade.

speech.para: Mr.Spence.- Where is the difference to the taxpayer?

talk.start.para: - It is certainly to the advantage of the taxpayer to keep trade, the loss of which would entail still heavier taxation.
- But the Americans undersell the Canadians at a loss.

- It is sometimes an advantage to sell at a loss. It appears to me that honorable members of the Opposition are in a difficulty. If those who are against bonuses vote for the retention of the amendment of the honorable member for Bland, they become State socialists, or, at any rate, will vote for what is State socialism, and I hardly think that the majority of those honorable members would care to be identified with that movement.
- The honorable member is prepared for State socialism, seeing that he is willing to give power to the Government to take the works over.

- I have no objection to the Government taking the works over if necessity arises ; but the honorable member for Bland contends that there should be no possibility of private enterprise. As I have said, I prefer that any provision as to purchase by the State should be omitted, but rather than see the industry thrown back as railway enterprise was in Queensland, I am prepared to accept the measure with a clause to that effect. I shall support the Government proposal.

- The question is not one of private enterprise versus State control, but whether we ought, as a Parliament, to assist private enterprise to the extent of a quarter of a million, and thus enable a syndicate to float a company. We have had a varied experience of such concessions, and I look on this as one of the most serious proposals of the kind which ever emanated from a Government. I am astonished to find the Minister for Trade and Customs fighting for the Bill, because hitherto I have recognised him as one who believed thoroughly in State control of large enterprises which come within the category of monopolies. The bonus will not be claimed by more than two companies, who will very soon beable to so arrange matters as to avoid competition.
- In Canada there are eight companies.
-There are many more than eight companies in Canada.

- The honorable member for Melbourne is a thorough believer in private enterprise, but we have had some very startling experience of State concessions, of which he knows something. This offer of £250,000 will enable a syndicate to appeal to British capitalists.
- It is not an offer of £250,000, but an offer of 12s. a ton.

- The maximum sum is £250,000, which will enable a syndicate to call in the aid of British capitalists and distinguished gentlemen in fixing up a very nice prospectus. A number of free shares will be given to those gentlemen, and when the company is started these shares, as is frequently done, will be unloaded on an unsuspecting public. When the enterprise collapses the public will have the shares, and the other people will have the money. Is it a proper thing for this Parliament to assist people to do that sort of thing? It has been done in Queensland and in other places several times. What experience have we had of private enterprise in South Australia recently? The Minister for Trade and Customs knows how much it was against his wish that the streets of Adelaide were given over to certain persons for the purpose of constructing privately- owned tramways. We were told that the enterprise would lead to opening up new avenues of work for the unemployed. Those who opposed the scheme were told that it was cruel to those who were out of work to offer opposition to the benevolent men who intended to spend half-a-million of money straight away upon the construction of the tramway system. Hundreds of the working classes supported the scheme, because they thought it meant more work for them. But what is the position today? The working classes have not had a penny out of it. Having secured the concession, the promoters are hawking it about in England for the purpose of promoting a company. It is more than three years since these promoters said that they had the capital, and that everything was ready to commence operations. All they wanted was the legislation to permit of the work being done. But all they have done up to the present has been to have a few loads of stone broken. The latest information we have is that one of the principals is drawing up elaborate plans, which are to be submitted to English investors. In the mean time no extra work has been found for the unemployed, and there is no guarantee that any will be found. What this Parliament isnow asked to do is to sanction the giving of £250,000 by way of bonuses at the rate of 1 2s. a ton for the production of pig-iron. That will be a great inducement for company promoters to parcel out shares as they have done on many occasions for their own benefit. So many free shares will be allotted, and so many to the promoters. Look at what has been done at Chillagoe.
- Who gets the free shares ?
- Certainly not the working man. At Chillagoe, where a big concession was granted, I venture to say that the people to-day rue that the claim was ever taken in hand.
- Is that the kind of private enterprise that was referred to by the honorable member for Melbourne?

- I donot want to refer to anything of a personal character in connexion with the matter, but the circumstances in regard to Chillagoe are well known to Victorians, who are acquainted with the scathing references that appeared in the press a little while ago.
- Is there not a difference between concessions in return for promises and payment for work done? In this case no company would receive payment until they had done the work.

speech.para: Mr.POYNTON.- As far as the actual payment is concerned, I agree that it would be possible to get money from the English public, and afterwards the promoters could sell out and leave the public with so much waste paper. It would be possible to get capital from the English public for any reasonable proposal by showing that the promoters have a guarantee from the Government of a bonus of 12s. a ton, or £250,000 as a maximum. That is a big lever to assist any one who goes to the English capitalist for money. I do not know why there should be such a hurry about this matter. The proposal was never put before the electors in a concrete form. They were never told that Parliament was to be asked tovote£250,000 of the taxpayers'money for such a purpose. The subject was not mentioned in the Governor-General's speech. Why should the matter not be allowed to stand over until the people have a chance of expressing their opinions about it? In less than eighteen months there will be a general election, when every constituency throughout the Commonwealth will have an opportunity to say whether it favours giving £250,000 to private enterprise for the purpose of carrying on the iron industry, or whether it is in favour of the States undertaking the work themselves. We are in the position of not knowing exactly where we are in regard to our finances. The Loan Bill has, been laid aside. A number of works that used to be undertaken by the States out of loan money are now to be paid for out of revenue. We also know that the revenue of some of the States is not as buoyant as we should like it to be. The result is that some of the States, in consequence of the action of this Parliament, will suffer a loss of revenue. In South Australia there has been a serious loss of revenue through the shrinkage of the railway receipts. I do not wish to be a croaker, but we cannot shut our eyes to the fact that, in consequence of the drought and from othercauses, this country has avery dark outlook before it. There has never been a time when the pinch was so serious as it is just now, and as it probably will be during the next twelve months. The revenue of the Commonwealth from customs and excise must be materially affected. In face of these facts, the Minister will be wise to allow the matter to stand over until after the next general election. In the meantime, if any of the States wish to undertake iron works they can do so. At present the States have had no chance to express their opinion adequately. It is true that the Ministerhas read letters showing that some of the States do not intend to embark upon such an enterprise, but there are often changes of opinion in connexion with such matters. There is no one in this House who is more sincere in regard to the State undertaking works than is the Minister for Trade and Customs. He has taken strong action in regard to the nationalization of works in South Australia. Therefore, I cannot understand why he is so anxious that private enterprise should undertake the iron industry, which comes within the category of works that ought to be controlled by the State. In any case, the manufacture of iron in this Commonwealth must be a monopoly.

talk.start.para: - How does the honorable member define monopoly in this connexion?

- I do not think that more than a couple of such works will be started in any case,and the tendency will be for the two companies not to compete against each other. If they are of equal strength, they will soon arrive at an agreement ; and if one company is stronger than the other, the weaker one will have to go down.
- Will notthe monopoly position be equally applicable to any one State that undertakes the work ? What is to prevent one State from squeezing the rest of the States of the Commonwealth?

- The difference is that a State would not work for the purpose of earning dividends on watered shares. In conclusion, I would remind the Minister of the somewhat chequered career of the Bill. If it had not been for the casting vote of Mr. Speaker the measure would have been referred to a select committee. That is very striking evidence that the House is very much divided upon the question whether the industry should be controlled by the State or private enterprise subsidized in the way proposed. Since then we have had a series of discussions on the Bill, and opinion is apparently almost equally divided in regard to whether now is the proper time toproceed with the project. In view of all these circumstances, I think the Minister would do well to allow the Bill to go to a select committee. If it were possible for an amendment now to be tabled to refer to a select committee the whole question of what the undertaking should be, I should vote for it in preference to allowing the bonus to be paid as proposed by the Government. If the Minister persists in dividing the committee on the Bill as it stands, without giving us any information of what further proposal he has to bring forward, I shall certainly vote as before for the retention of the proviso inserted by the honorable member for Bland.

- Honorable members will remember that when the Bill was last before us, I was one of those who, whilst they could not see their way to vote against it, as they were deeply impressed with the importance of establishing the industry, thought that the Government should have withheld the proposal until they were prepared to submit fuller particulars to Parliament, to enable us to deal with it in the light of the fullest information. The clause now before us proposes that the industry shall be a State monopoly, and I am afraid some honorable members may not have weighed fully what the consequences would be if it were carried. I am as favorably disposed towards the establishment of the industry by the State as is any honorable member, and I should be very pleased indeed to see it taken up by one of the States. But if we pass the Bill in its present form, and the industry is not taken, up by any of the States' Governments - as I believe it will not be - the effect will be to shut out private enterprise altogether.
- It would give notice of a powerful competitor.

- There would be the possibility not only of a powerful competitor against any private enterprise, but of a State as a competitor assisted by a bonus. Several persons who are interested in the iron industry have assured me that not one shilling would be invested in it while this provision remained. I can understand the attitude of those honorable members who, upon principle, are opposed to bonuses, but nevertheless may be very favorable to the establishment of the industry by private enterprise. That is a consistent attitude to adopt, but I would point out that the retention of the proviso in this clause would shut out the possibility of private enterprise. Private individuals would recognise at once the seriousness ofembarking their capital in the industry, when there was a prospect of a State Government, assisted by a large Government bonus, entering into competition with them.
- That is an argument that the industry would be a monopoly.

- It has nothing to do with the question of monopoly. If my honorable friend were a member of a private company which proposed to invest several hundred thousand pounds in the industry, he would surely object to the adoption of that course if he believed that the Government of any State, supported by a Government bonus, was likely to enter into competition with it. A private company would be placed at such a disadvantage that it would not be likely to enter upon the work. I would rather see the Bill lost than passed with this proviso in it, because I believe it would have the effect of effectually shutting out private enterprise. I would ask those honorable members who are opposed to the payment of a bonus in any shape or form, but who are friendly to the establishment of the industry by private enterprise to give that aspect of the case careful consideration. It was very strongly impressed upon me by gentlemen who are interested in this industry that they would not invest one shilling of their capital in it if the measure were placed upon the statute-book in its present form.

speech.para: Mr.FOWLER (Perth).- There are two aspects of this subject for which I am unable to find any satisfactory explanation in my own mind, nor have I obtained it from any honorable member. In the first place, I cannot understand the reason for the haste shown by the Minister in charge of the Bill. I cannot see any great national calamity behind the possibility that this project may be set aside for a little while until we see how we stand financially.
